results.title: Hullabaloo over Georgie & Bonnie's pictures
results.creator_credit: James Ivory, Ismail Merchant, London Weekend Television and Merchant Ivory Productions
results.brief_description: The “hullaballo” in question is a leisurely, but fiercely determined race for possession of a priceless collection of rare Indian pictures. It’s enlivened by a romp through royal India…a world of princes, palaces, tourists, precious art objects and their wheelers and dealers… but more than this, the film gives us rare insight into the lasting values of life. The films boasts a wonderful screenplay by Ruth Prawer Jhabuala. Stars Peggy Ashcroft.

results.title: Hugo
results.headline_credit: France, United Kingdom and United States of America, 2011
results.brief_description: Orphaned except for an uncle, Hugo Cabret lives in the walls of a train station in 1930s Paris. His job is to oil and maintain the station’s clocks, but he’s more interested in protecting a broken automaton and notebook left to him by his late father.

constellations_other.name: The LumiÃ¨re brothers
constellations_other.description: The LumiÃ¨re brothers understood the potential of cinema to be exhibited theatrically. Only one person could watch films through Thomas Edison's Kinetograph, while Auguste and Louis exhibited their films to thousands with Cinematographe.

constellations_other.name: Innovation, technology and design: Edweard Muybridge
constellations_other.description: A focus on the discovery, inspiration and innovation at the heart of moving image history

constellations_other.name: Analogue and digital film
constellations_other.description: Though technology has evolved since celluloid film strips were invented, contemporary filmmakers and artists still appreciate and celebrate the analogue in a digital world.

results.headline_credit_for_label: France, United Kingdom and United States of America, 2011
results.description: Orphaned and alone except for an uncle, Hugo Cabret lives in the walls of a train station in 1930s Paris. Hugo’s job is to oil and maintain the station’s clocks, but to him, his more important task is to protect a broken automaton and notebook left to him by his late father. Accompanied by the goddaughter of an embittered toy merchant, Hugo embarks on a quest to solve the mystery of the automaton and find a place he can call home.

Accompanied by the goddaughter of an embittered toy merchant, Hugo embarks on a quest to solve the mystery of the automaton and find a place he can call home.

results.title: Hug me
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, Nick Bosustow, Churchill Films and Bosustow Entertainment
results.brief_description: An animated story of a lonely porcupine who wants a friend to hug him more than anything else in the world, but who is shunned by the other animals. He eventually finds such a friend in the forest. Based on the book “Hug me” by Patti Stren.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sam Weiss, Nick Bosustow, Churchill Films and Bosustow Entertainment

results.title: Huey Long
results.creator_credit: David L. Wolper, Walter Reade and Sterling Productions
results.brief_description: A biographical film on the life of Louisianna’s infamous governor Huey Long. Using photographs and archival footage, this documentary focuses on his political career as Railroad Commisioner, Governor of Louisianna and US Senator and touches on his aspirations for the US presidency. Promoting himself as an enemy of large corporations and a champion of the ‘common man’ his social platform revolved around public works programmes and social services. Allegations of bribery and corruption instigated actions to remove him from local and national politicals. Long was assasinated in 1935 by Carl White, a young doctor who’s family had been persecuted by Long. The archival film that was sourced for this documentary include footage of Mardi Gas and jazz scenes of New Orleans in the 20’s; armed police supporting Huey Long; Louisianna’s political heavyweights during Long’s reign; and a memorable performance by Huey Long singing his election song ‘Everyman a king’. Commentary by Mike Wallace.

results.title: Hue and cry
results.creator_credit: Charles Crichton, Henry Cornelius, Sir Michael Balcon, Rank Film Productions and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
While reading a hair-rasing serial in the magazine “The Trump”, 15 year-old Joe Kirby finds that his over-active imagination has exceeded itself and he lands right in the middle of the story. Joe convinces himself and friends that the magazine installments are being used as a means of secret communication by a masterly gang of criminals. Starring Alastair Sim, Jack Warner, Valerie White and Jack Lambert.

results.title: Hue
results.brief_description:
Hue is a stark puzzle platformer where you shift the hue of the world, creating rifts when colours collide.

In this world, everyone sees in grayscale. Anne, a researcher specialising in colour theory, has created a mysterious ring which grants the ability to perceive and alter colour. After a fracas with her research assistant, she disappears into a coloured void. You play as Hue, Anneâ€™s son, as he discovers fragments of his missing motherâ€™s research and learns to perceive and alter colour for the first time.

constellations_other.name: Colour and illusion
constellations_other.description: Exploring the science of colour, light, reflection and movement.

results.title: Hudson 70
results.creator_credit: National Film Board of Canada and Crawley Films
results.brief_description: The circumnavigation of the continents of North and South America, for long a navigator’s dream, was accomplished in 1970 by the Canadian Scientific Ship “Hudson” as part of Canada’s commitment to the International Oceanographic Decade, a project of UNESCO. Here is the ship’s log, detailing the many kinds of research in which the “Hudson” engaged. The last phase of the 47,000 mile voyage documented, for the first time, scientific investigations of the polar seas above Canada.

results.title: Hudson
results.creator_credit: Robert Heazlewood, Tasmanian Television and Corporate Communications
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Player Profile Series”.
Football statistics reveal that there has never been a finer spearhead in the history of Australian Rules Football than Peter Hudson. Historical highlights and interviews provide an insight into the game’s most potent offensive player and prolific goal kicking machine.

results.title: Hud
results.brief_description: Based on Larry McMurtry’s novel about the experiences of a young boy growing up in Texas, “Hud” is a powerful story of family corruption and betrayal. Lone (Brandon de Wilde) is a teenager in a sleepy Texas town whose hero is his cavalier uncle, Hud (Paul Newman). Hud is the new face of the West. Unlike his father he refuses traditional values based on hard work and community and instead stands for a new creed of economic selfishness and sexual amorality. Hud’s bitter relationship with his father (Melvyn Douglas) comes to a head when a mysterious illness starts attacking their cattle. As the two men fight it out, Lone has to choose between the two men and decide for himself what kind of man he wishes to become. The makers of “Hud”, many of whom were blacklisted in the 1950s, have lovingly recreated the bleakness and beauty of a desert community. They have also created one of the first modern westerns, a film which challenges the myths of the Wild West and instead powerfully examines the reality of social, economic and gender relationships in rural America. The stunning black and white photography is by acclaimed cinematographer James Wong Howe and the music score is by Elmer Bernstein. Melvyn Douglas won an Academy Award for his performance, as did Patricia Neal, who as the divorcee housekeeper who knows her time and her looks are fading, gives one of the great performances of the 1960s.
